summary: In Ribeiro v Ribeiro, the Supreme Court of Ghana delivered a split decision (3-2) on the interpretation of the Matrimonial Causes Act, 1971 (Act 367), particularly regarding the court's power to rescind property dispositions made to defeat financial claims and to award financial provision. The wife, Barbara Ribeiro, successfully obtained a decree of divorce and sought financial relief, including property reassignment and maintenance. The High Court ordered the husband, Charles Ribeiro, to convey 'Haulage House' to her and pay �150,000, citing his transfer of the property to his new wife during proceedings as a bad-faith attempt to defeat her claim. The Court of Appeal upheld this decision. The Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings by majority, recognizing broad judicial discretion under sections 20 and 26 of Act 367. However, two justices dissented, arguing that courts lack authority to transfer property in which the spouse holds no title and that financial provision should be limited to monetary awards.
rationaleHighlights: Court may rescind property transfers made in bad faith to defeat financial claims
Non-financial contributions (e.g., homemaking) justify financial provision
Discretion under Act 367 includes property conveyance, not just monetary awards
Dissent argued courts cannot transfer property without proprietary interest
Affluent spouse may be required to provide housing as part of financial relief
English precedents inform but do not bind Ghanaian interpretation
Transfer during proceedings with continued control indicates fraudulent intent
Legislative clarity needed on scope of financial provision powers
confidenceNotes: High confidence in factual accuracy based on detailed judicial reasoning and cited statutes. Some interpretive divergence noted in dissenting opinions.
